reasoning:
1. Circle of Competence: Apple sits squarely in my circle of competence—like Coke or See’s Candies, it’s a consumer products business riding a powerful ecosystem and brand. I understand how people get locked into those iPhones, iPads and Macs.  
2. Competitive Moat: The 42.6% operating margin and 85% performance stability tell you there’s real pricing power and switching costs in that ecosystem. But inconsistent ROE—only 5 out of the last 10 years above 15%—hints at bumps in the road.  
3. Management & Capital Allocation: Tim Cook and team have been honest operators, but a recent stock issuance dilutes value and dividends remain minimal. Berkshire likes share buybacks when a business is unloved; issuing more stock feels like the tail wagging the dog.  
4. Financial Health & Consistency: Strong ROE (19.4%) and throaty operating margins are great, but a 4.0 debt-to-equity ratio surprises me in a company sitting on piles of cash. And earnings growth has been lumpy—10% over ten periods isn’t exactly the steady march I prefer.  
5. Valuation vs. Intrinsic Value: Your DCF pegs intrinsic at roughly $84,700 on a conservative basis, meaning Apple is trading well above that (negative 95% margin of safety). As I’ve always said, “Price is what you pay, value is what you get.” Today you’re paying up for future promise that’s already priced in.  
6. Long-Term Prospects & Red Flags: I like Apple’s long-term proposition—after all, I’ve owned it for years. Yet negative growth assumptions in stages 1 and 2 signal the market expects headwinds, and I don’t see a big margin of safety. No business lasts forever unchallenged.  
7. Opportunity Cost: I’d rather pick off shares of Coca-Cola at a reasonable price or add to Bank of America while it’s beaten up. Even GEICO or BNSF units can be bought with a margin of safety.  
Conclusion: Apple is a wonderful business, but not at today’s price. I’d pass on adding here—no point in overpaying for greatness.

fundamental_analysis.details: Strong ROE of 19.4%; High debt to equity ratio of 4.0; Strong operating margins; Current ratio data not available

consistency_analysis.details: Inconsistent earnings growth pattern; Total earnings growth of 10.0% over past 10 periods

moat_analysis.details: Inconsistent ROE: only 5/10 periods >15%; Strong and stable operating margins (avg: 42.6%) indicate pricing power moat; High performance stability (85.1%) suggests strong competitive moat

book_value_analysis.details: Inconsistent book value per share growth

management_analysis.details: Recent common stock issuance (potential dilution); No or minimal dividends paid

details: Using three-stage DCF: Stage 1 (-1.3%, 5y), Stage 2 (-0.7%, 5y), Terminal (2.5%)
